Welcome. Hello. Furthermore, I actually grew up
in San Jose in Almaden Valley,

so I'm very much a
Silicon Valley native. And so in some
ways, this talk is

about what I've been doing
since I left the Bay Area. Silicon Valley native California
optimist goes to the big city

and what's happened since. And so I moved to
New York City in 2018

very much to join Cornell Tech. So this picture here is
like a digital rendering

of the Cornell Tech campus. That long tall
rectangle is actually

the house, the high rise that
the student faculty live in. I live on the 25th
floor of that. The little buildings
at the base of that

are actually the research
and office buildings for Cornell Tech. And that's where I work
when I'm not on sabbatical,

which I am this year. I avoid all these
places except the cafe. It's actually the Queensboro
Bridge there in the backdrop.

For oldsters, people
who like things, that's actually the bridge that
the Simon Garfunkel feeling

Groovy is about. It's a Groovy place. Queensboro Bridge
actually doesn't

stop on Roosevelt Island. It flies over. That island is in the middle of
the East River between Manhattan

and Queens. Officially as part of Manhattan,
but it's a little bit isolated. And Cornell Tech is a graduate
school and research center

for Cornell University,
which is up in Ithaca, closer to Niagara Falls.

This was established after
winning this competition to build a applied science
campus on the island.

And I say this not to
gloat because when Cornell won this competition
over Stanford,

I was a member of Stanford. It was a friend of mine-- friends of mine that were
there standing on the hills,

imagining what Stanford
could be there. And so it's funny
that I'm there now. But the mission of the campus is
to emphasize applying technology

to real world challenges,
engaging with external partners. The competition
to have the campus

was in large part spurred
by the 2008 recession when Bloomberg
realized there needed

to be just a lot more
diversification of the economy in New York City. And now, New York City is
second to some other place

in the world for startups and
new ventures and technology. So this campus is
small part of that,

but it's exciting to be there. So I'm going to tell you guys
about three lines of research

from my current
research program that fit underneath the theme
of urban interaction.

These are not finished projects. One of the lovely things about
being an associate professor

is you can start projects
that don't have a clear end and just do them because
you think they're exciting.

And so I'm very much
grabbing the reins for that. And some of these
things have-- they really long threads
and some of them

go all the way back to
my days at Stanford, so I'm quite excited
to tell you about them. So I'm just going to tell
you-- at the forefront,

I'm going to tell
you about trash bots in the city, urban
fingerprinting and then communal extended reality.

So leading off, I'm
going to show you this video, which is from work
that we did in 2014 and 2015

at Stanford. And I don't even know if some
of these places still exist, but let's see. Maybe you'll recognize them.

So these are the
results of what we call phenomenological experiments. We basically wanted
understand how

people are going to interact
with robots in the future when we can imagine they
might be running around. And we could ask people--

we could just make things
and foist them on people. But I think one
of the things that is really interesting
about interaction

is that it's like a dialogue. You really can't author
a dialogue by yourself. What you say influences what the
next person says and influences

what you are going to say. And so you can really
only understand these things in a
context where you

are interacting with
the people you're planning to interact with. So we run these
experiments in part

to underline the point that
Cliff Nass used to make, which is that people interact
socially with computers.

And a lot of people in the
human robot interaction space uses a reason to
justify why we have to make everything
have eyes and hands

because people are expecting
to interact socially. And one of the things that
we are trying to point out is that people will
interact socially regardless

of what the machine looks like. And so our robot
doesn't look anything like anything else except just
normal brute trash barrel.

But you can see people doing all
sorts of social interactions. And I think some of the
things that we've shown here have been replicated
in other places.

But some of the things
that really jump out to me is how much pre-interaction
goes into an interaction. People are negotiating we're
not going to interact because we

don't have any garbage. So they're interacting to say
we're not going to interact and they're explaining what the
preconditions for interaction

would have been. That's fascinating. I don't know a single
robot that's actually looking for those signs,
but it's actually really,

really important. Another thing is
about the mental model people have for the robot.

We laughed ourselves
silly when we found that clip of that kid
trying to bait the garbage

can across the floor to where
he wanted to go with garbage. Because the mental model
there is the garbage can wants to eat the garbage.

We're like, that is amazing. We should give him money. But then as we started to
look at this other footage,

we're like, that's
actually implicitly in a lot of the other things
that people are doing. They think they can
make the robot do things

or not do things by
moving the garbage around. And this is a great
example of mental models. Everyone can see that
that's a garbage can.

It doesn't have a
digestive system. It has no desire to eat.

And we don't do
anything to tell people how to interact with the
robot, but the number of times that people
obviously use a model where

the garbage can has a
desire to eat garbage is really astonishing. And one of the
things I love is--

what's going on is
that we have permission to run the experiment. We only use the
footage from people

who give us permission to use
it, and we do a post interview. And sometimes, the people who
are remotely operating the trash

barrel don't see people
who are doing things like basically throwing the
garbage over the shoulder

of the garbage can. And when we interview
those people, they're angry because they
gave the garbage cans something

and they weren't acknowledged. So age model, human model
for interaction, someone

comes and takes your
garbage, you thank them. Here, people expect
to be thanked.

So the interaction model is a
social interaction model but not a human social
interaction model. And I think that's
super fascinating.

And this is the
thing that you can't learn without actually being in
the space and trying things out. So going to New York, one of the
things we wanted to understand

is it the same in the
city, across the world? It turns out later on
eight years later--
let's see.

And we made two robots to
separate landfill and recycling. Our study area is constrained
within the trapezium shaped

traffic island called Astor
Place in Manhattan, New York City. The space is set up with
several metal tables

and chairs for public seating. We used a Wizard of
Oz deployment method to elicit natural
interaction behaviors

from people who perceive
our robots to be autonomous.
There you go.
I need you Yeah. Come on. Yeah. Yeah.
It's trash here. Yes. Yes. Oh, good boy.
There you go. Good boy. It's recycling. You're a bad boy.

You don't know
what you're doing.  It's OK.
They're learning. They're learning. It still helps

I thought it was someone
just rolling away from someone earlier. And then I realize
they're buddies

and they're here
to do their job. So people can just toss? I guess it knows I've been
sitting here long enough.
I should give it something. OK. Come here, buddy.
Thank you. Good job.
That's creepy. That's just freaking creepy. I could tell you.
So you know it's New York.
What does he want? That cup, bro. I will give you my straw.

OK. I don't know. This makes you believe
in social science. We're getting a lot of the
same kinds of behaviors

eight years later a
whole nation away. And you can see people still
think that the robots is

eating garbage. They still talk to
it like it's a dog. They say things
like it's learning. Huge assumption for a machine
that you see in public.

It's learning. They're still learning. And this idea that you could
train them and say things to them.

We're not building machines that
are picking up on these signals, but people clearly
expect that de novo.

So it's really cool. One of the interesting things
about doing these kinds of field

experiments in the
wild is you just don't control so much
of the environment. One thing that we get as
questions from reviewers

is, how do you keep repeat
interactions from happening? Like we can't. And sometimes we do get
people that see it again.

You see successive things. And we also don't control
like social media.

So a lot of people
end up finding out about something that's happening
as we're doing the experiments. They come explicitly
to find the robots.

Here is something
that someone sent me. Tiffany saying--
a friend of mine, she found this
TikTok video and I

just-- this is so amazing
because we would never have learned any of the things
that were captured by this video
with the NYC sanitation budget.

OK. So one thing that is
really interesting is nobody ever asks us when we
are doing the post interview,

how does that robot work? This is the thing we're so
proud of-- how the robot works, how remotely controlling. It's like recycled
hoverboards underneath that we

have managed to hack. So we do that. No one cares about that. A lot of people ask, actually
where does the video footage go?

Does it get retained? Who uses it? And this is, I think, a really
interesting post George Floyd thing.

No one used to ask us
about these things before, but now people are
very conscious of it. And it's a nice
conversation actually

to have with the public. But the thing that we get asked
the most is who's robot is it?

Because that's for them, quite
important to thinking about how they want to interact
with the robot. It's not the robot.

They understand the robot
is an agent of someone. Who? Mayor Eric Adams.

And why is it there? It's the sanitation budget. And of course, in Manhattan,
they have robot trash barrels.

And the comments to this TikTok
video were just so illuminating. Issues that we never
thought of being raised.

So this one says, yeah, now
deploy it to all the Boroughs.

And then someone says, I
agree I was being sarcastic, but it's a waste of money,
especially when your New

York has crime going on. And then other people were like,
it wouldn't work in the Bronx.

And someone says, you have--
there's so many neighbors in the Bronx, the
need of cleanup, and this is what we get.

And so I will say
that for us, this was like a real inspiration.

Like yeah, OK, we're in-- it was such a big
deal just to be in the real city
with real passers by,

not just a bunch of
Stanford students. That's not real people. We are like there in
the middle of Manhattan. But actually yeah, every one of
the neighborhoods in the Bronx

has own character. What is that? We have not managed to get
a foothold in the Bronx yet, but last summer, we were
able to do a deployment.

Sorry. I don't know which-- yeah. So this is the comments
that people are making.

We managed to do a deployment
in downtown Brooklyn. I'm just going to show
you a few clips showing

the differences between what's
happening in Astor Place, which is in the middle of Manhattan,
and Albee Plaza, which
is in downtown Brooklyn.
Yeah. Just had too much. Hi.
I don't have any trash.  No trash here.

This is that negotiating
whether preconditions

are for interaction. They try and explain. We're not going to--
we have no trash. But also very Gen Z.
This one negotiating

another part of this-- I'm really excited. I have a whole deck of people
explaining things to robots.

And this is another one, someone
basically negotiating when the end of the interaction is.
Thank you very much.

No, that was it. So there's some difficult
paving that's going on.

Sometimes the robots
get a little stuck. But people are
quite nervous when the robot overstays its
welcome because they're like,

no, we're done. So they're friendly, and
then this kind of stop. And then this.

We saw this earlier,
but I think this is it's a fun thing to see
what it's like from the robots perspective.
Yes. Here we go.
Come on. No. Yeah. No, I need you.
I need you. Yeah. Come on. Yeah. Yeah.
It's trash here. Yes.
Yes. Good boy. Good boy.

It's recycling. You're a bad boy. You don't know
what you're doing.
It's OK. They're learning. They're learning. They're still pups. They're still pups.
This is Albee Plaza.

So downtown Brooklyn is a
little bit more neighborhoody.
People hang out there. Excuse me. I'm having my ice cream.
It ain't empty.
Hello. I'm still having my ice cream. Get away from me. I have no garbage.

Hello. Hello. OK. So the expectation
that this person

thinks the robot
remembers them, they're continuing the conversation
they had before. And you can hear the
annoyance and the voice

because they didn't learn
the lesson last time. So there's just much more
pointed enunciation of the thing

that she wants the
robot to understand. I just think is amazing. And that's something
that happens when people are expecting
repeated interactions.

This is a space where people see
the same people all the time. And we also saw this here.
[SPEAKING SPANISH]
I love it. Thank you.

They're teasing it. They're teasing
the trash barrel.
[SPEAKING SPANISH]
Now they're helping to fix it. [SPEAKING SPANISH] Now it has a nickname.
Thank you so much.

OK. We are spending a lot of time
with different ethnographers, linguists kind of analyzing
the footage that we have here.

And we're also trying to
set up other deployments. And the other Boroughs-- I think Queens is next.

Bronx is actually still
the kind of Holy Grail. But the high level point is that
even very simple machines elicit

these very rich interactions. And the thing that
is amazing is the way that the interaction
is similar but not

the same in different contexts. And as a designer, that's
a fascinating thing to think about and
try to understand how we're going to grapple with.

How do we get
enough data that we can understand these
fine grained distinctions between places?

And one thing I think
is really interesting is that in some
ways, you can say we can learn these
things from the people.

They're constantly signaling
to the robots what's expected. This is a little
weird but amazing.

And I think this points out
something about culture. Culture is self-perpetuating. This is the metaphor.

There's all sorts of people who
have an investment in the way things are, and they have--

then they take upon themselves
the job of training newcomers to understand the
way things are.

So this comes off
in positive ways. Social norm kind of
acculturation, and also negative

ways, bullying. But it's really interesting
that the culture perpetuates differences in ways that
are worth understanding

because very often
as technologists, the attitude is we will
just introduce a thing and then everyone
everywhere will adapt.

And they just aren't
paying attention to the role that culture plays
and the incentives that people have for perpetuating culture
and really getting rid

of things that don't fit in. And you actually see this
in the autonomous car space. So I think as HCI people, low
cost, easily replicable methods

and probes and data
sharing makes it possible for us to grapple with the
breadth and depth of data

that you actually
need to understand these cultural differences. And I will say we're kind of at
the beginning phases of this,

but we put the plans for
our trash probe online. My partner in crime, Barry
Brown at Copenhagen University,

has had his not technical-- [INAUDIBLE] students actually
replicate the machine and run

some experiments in their world. And one of the things that
we're trying to figure out is basically how we all
share these things in ways

that preserve privacy
for all the participants but allow us to really get
at the ways interaction

is the same in different places. All right. So the city is a great
place to look at culture
is the takeaway theme.

All right. So the next bit I'm
going to talk about is urban fingerprinting. And we will go basically from
the sidewalk level, which

just happens when you're
sitting around a cafe table to this more grand view.

A lot of times, we have this
map level view of cities. You can see the geography
in a way that as a person,

we don't get to see. And actually, this
topic, what I'm calling urban
fingerprinting, is the thing

that was just presented. So I was general chair of the
automotive UI conference, which just happened Sunday
to Wednesday this week

here at Paul Brest Hall
on the Stanford campus. And this is actually
a paper from one of my students, which is--

from several of my
students called Towards the Instrumented Fingerprinting
of Urban Traffic. And it's a way that
uses mobile dash

cams to get a picture
for what we kind of see going on everywhere in the
city but we can't understand

the whole citywide Vibes, my Gen Z
students call it.

This work came out
of the pandemic. So during the pandemic,
I had a problem where my students, New
York City people, who

like to be around other people
kept sneaking into the lab. So I needed to find
a way to get them all

to be doing COVID 19
research so that we weren't violating campus policy.

We started studying
social distancing. And we have a lot of stuff
where we have instrumented vehicles that look at how people
are interacting on the street.

And what we proposed-- we got
an NSF rapid grant to look at was whether people were
distancing in public.

This is before we knew
that in the outdoors, you don't need to really be
worried about social distancing so much. But as part of this, we
were driving our car around

and taking a lot of videos and
images of what was going around and then running
computer vision on it

and recognizing people,
seeing if people were in different
kinds of uniforms

and just trying to
surmise where are people are gathering in
the moment in time

that we're supposed to be
publicly social distancing. As part of this, we
learned that there's

a lot of these large
urban data sets. We were using this
program called Mapillary, which got purchased
by Facebook slash Meta.

But we were using that
to aggregate our data. So we could-- if we
had a stream of data,

basically, the Mapillary would
capture all these streams and then if you
made your data open, you can actually share your data
with other people who are also

putting their dashcam data,
bicycle data, pedestrian data up online.

We could also get a lot. We could kind of-- because
our sampling was really

opportunistic, it was useful
that the New York DOT also has these traffic cameras. We were scraping the
traffic cameras quite often.

So we'd get to something
closer to ground truth that we could actually use
to validate the data that we were collecting.

But one of the things
that we learned is that a company
called Nexar, they make a network dash cameras.

They're in a lot of
the Ubers, Lyfts, taxi cabs in New York City. And they basically can get the
equivalent of Google Street

View 8 to 10 times a day. And so we quickly moved
from capturing our own data

to asking Nexar for data
from different points in time to understand what's
going on in the city.

And by doing large scale
computer vision recognition, we can see different things
that are going on in the city.

For instance, my PhD
student, Matt Franchi, has done this work
to train something

to recognize police
vehicles in these frames. And then here's
classification at AUC.

And then we can use
that to actually see where there are more and
less police cars in the city. And this is actually not a
totally straightforward thing

because we don't actually know
what the sampling for these dash cams are, and neither
will they tell us, because that's kind of
own corporate secret.

So we have to do different
kinds of things with the data to make sure that we're
doing good sampling.

And what we can find are
things that are not surprising. These are things that are
known, but that there's just many, many more police
in the commercial areas

than in the residentials
in this areas in the city. That there's a lot
more police presence

in the lowest quartile
income neighborhoods than in the higher
income neighborhoods.

And also Black and
Hispanic neighborhoods have far more police presence
than the White or Asian

communities. So this is a really
interesting thing. You get a feeling for this when
you walk out onto the street. But beginning the
data is really hard.

And it's actually
really difficult because you get the data
from the very people that you're trying to audit. So being able to have
other sidewalk level

ways of getting information
about what we care about in the city is
really interesting.

Another thing that
we've used this data for is looking at the
scaffolds in New York City. So for those of
you who don't know,

we have this situation
where building people who live in a building
are liable for anyone

that gets harmed by
stuff falling off the front of the building. And so if you're
repairing your building, you have to have scaffolds up.

And if you are
repairing your building but can't afford to
finish, it's better to leave the scaffold up
sometimes for multiple decades.

And to take them
down-- and it becomes a blight in and of itself. It creates an opportunities
for crime and garbage and things like that.

So one thing that we were
able to do is basically do-- and this is a wonderful
intern of ours,

who was able to go through
the data set that we have and look to see every place
that there is recognizable

scaffolding and then compare
that to what the New York City Department of Buildings has
for permanent scaffolding

and find all the
unpermitted scaffolding. And that makes it
possible for people who are building inspectors. It's actually only a handful
of people for a huge city

to figure out where
to go and look at what is the problem here,
how can we address that? So that's something that's
like-- we have up on archive.

Still trying to get published. And then one of
the things that we were addressing in the work
that was presented at AutoUI

is like, how much can we use
this method to fingerprint cities? You can't get at ground truth
because of the sampling issues.

But can we, with
this method, actually do enough sampling that we can
characterize how one city is

like or not like another city? And that tells us
something about how much we can take policies, interventions
that are introduced in one place

and how we might expect
it to go in another place. So from that perspective,
we also looked at the data

that you can get
from San Francisco. And you see there
are some issues.

This is a density of the images
that we have in New York City. And it's less in San
Francisco, mostly because I think I told
you these things are

captured from dash cameras or
in these rideshare vehicles. And even though there are
many, many rideshare vehicles in San Francisco,
it's dwarfed compared

to the number of
rideshare vehicles that are instrumented
in San Francisco. So it looks like
there's a thing that we

might be able to do in cities
where there's enough cars, there's instrumentation. But it also points
to something else.

Like we could be
having the buses, municipal fleet vehicles
and other things that are instrumented this way
and cities could be running

their own version of
these large urban data sets to get information about
what's going on in the city all the time.

So the takeaway I want for
this thread of research is it's really
challenging to capture

the everyday sense
of the city at scale, and large urban image
data sets give us

a way to map urban scale
trends while preserving kind of the everyday person's
ability to audit the data.

Because we get these
maps all the time but do you know if they're true? The fact that you can
just look at the picture

is kind of amazing. Ground truth is
elusive at this scale. And so it's possible
to characterize

key differences
between cities, and I think that is a really
interesting endeavor. And we hypothesize
that these fingerprints

can help us to contextualize
findings and expectations for generalizability across
cities, which has always

been something that's developed
urban scale social science. Everything happens. Everyone studies New York
because they put their data out

and nobody knows how much
you can take that away. And we think this might be a way
that you can actually figure out how much you can transfer stuff.

I just want to
emphasize-- again, we have the anonymized
data set available. We're trying to encourage other
people to do what we're doing.

All right. Last thread of research
revolves around

communal extended reality. So Michael mentioned--
we've actually been doing a lot of work
looking at how people interact

with automated vehicles. That's been a kind
of theme of mine. And one of the things that
has come from that research

is just much more engagement
with virtual reality simulation as a tool.

I will just say
at the forefront, I really don't like
using virtual reality

as a consumer product. I get ill. I love the physical world. I love being with
all of the grit

and the reality of people
and virtual reality doesn't have some
of these things. But as a research tool,
it's been super amazing.

And so what I'm
really interested in is how people interact
with one another

and how we get information
about how people interact with one another. So I'm just going to say,
I think from a classic HCI

perspective, if you want to know
what people think, you ask them. One of the design in
HCI kind of discoveries

is that people can't tell
you what they don't know. So if you ask them
about future scenarios,

they'll give you an answer but
you can't trust the answer. So it's useful to show up with
a prototype, many prototypes

and get their reactions
to those things. You just basically bring a
little artifact from the future and getting their
reaction to something.

So now you have a real
reaction to a possible thing. At the city scale, we
basically use simulation

to prototype scenarios,
environments, design interventions in ways that
lets the users react naturally.

So we joke about it. It's like real reactions
to fake situations. And so one of the things I'm
really, really interested in

is just this thing
that happens every day but we don't have a lot of
data about, which is how people interact just in intersections.

And so we built this strange
land driving simulator where you can have two people
in the same virtual world, each

in their own virtual
cars, kind of Mario Kart, but we use that
to look at the way that people use the
vehicles to communicate

who's going to go first,
who's going to go second and how those things are the
same in different places.

Virtual reality headset
driving simulation at two locations with
170 participants.

This study focused on the role
of social situational awareness. Short essay of drivers
during an encounter

culminating in crossing
an intersection safely. Two drivers each drove
their own virtual cars

in the same virtual world
and encountered one another in scenarios of approaching
and crossing intersections.

Social essay of other
drivers direction of approach to the intersection,
signaling, speed and speed

change and heading of the
vehicle were measured. Essay scores and models
of the encounters

reflect sequential
perception and understanding of explicit cues such as
signaling and implicit cues

with speed change being the
strongest one, and expectations of the other driver's actions
all highly related to awareness

to who entered the
intersection first. We propose implications to
driver-to-driver communications

and negotiations and
to AV design that is situationally aware to
ensure driver social aspects

in the encounter.  I think the beginning
of this video,

we say we present findings. And this is a little bit the
paradigm in social science. We only have facts about people.

Facts about people, right? I think one of the interesting
things about this method that we're using is what we're
collecting is these movement

patterns. And a lot of times,
what we get out of this are these movement models that
could be used if you were like,

for example, like programming
an AV to recognize what the communicative intent
of another car's movement is

or how it should move to
communicate that it's going to go or it's not going to go. And these are a little
bit less findings.

It doesn't actually fit the Ted
X. Like here's a strange thing that you didn't know that
I'm going to tell you model of research,
but I think this

is the more valuable
and actionable research. And I think for me, I'm actually
less excited about this work

and more excited about
this follow on work, which looks at how drivers and
pedestrians interact,

because the pedestrians
outside the car didn't sign up for this future
with autonomous vehicles, don't want to have
to deal with it,

but still the
vehicles are there, and it would be great
if those vehicles really took into account the way
that people move their bodies

and signal when they're
going to go or not go. So this is actually a work
that's still in progress. We just demoed it
at AutoUI this week.

I have a video in the
upper left hand corner showing what's going on in
the real world environment.

And then on the upper right, the
virtual world, third party view. And then in the lower left,
the driver's perspective

and the lower right, a
pedestrians perspective. And this is a street crossing,
what we call a pop out scenario

where a pedestrian
seems to come out from behind a
vehicle for the car.

And what we hear is
what the pedestrian hears in their earpiece.

Please stop.  So the kinds of things
that we can get from this

is we basically have
these motion capture-- we can basically see when
people are gesturing, how they like gaze and look.

It's a little bit
less cool findings, but the way that people use
their bodies differently in different places.

And one of the things that
I think is an early thing, and you're like, if
it's what you know, there are places
where people perform

not looking like
in New York City and they move with

You back far enough away

the data that signals

when one context is
in play versus another is really important. Here's another way that
we're using simulation

to look at how people interact. In this case, we're
actually comparing on road to in-lab scenarios.

We have designed an on
road driving simulation infrastructure named
Portobello that

allows drivers or passengers
in cars wearing mixed reality headsets to see virtual
objects overlaid on top

of their real world view. To date, simulators
with this capability have been unable to replicate
the types of driving

studies typically performed
in in-lab simulators. Portobello makes it possible
to port studies developed

for in lab simulators to be
run on road, a functionality that we call
platform portability.

To achieve platform
portability, we have applied sensing and
localization technologies from robotics and
autonomous vehicle research

to stage virtual events
in the world frame. A LiDAR and IMU are
used to localize

the vehicle in the world
frame, and infrared tracking is used to localize
the participant's head

movement within the vehicle. To validate our system, we ran
the same autonomous vehicle

interaction study in both
on-roadour on-road driving simulator and an in-lab
driving simulator,

an approach we call
twinning of studies. We were able to port
our study design, which involves having
participants assist

an autonomous vehicle
in determining when it was safe or not safe to drive
when virtual pedestrians were

present. With our system, people are
able to see virtual avatars exactly where they
were programmed

in their corresponding
location in the real world. The workflow to make platform
portable study designs

requires mapping of the real
world course environment. We first scan the test area and
obtain a high resolution point

cloud map of the environment. A point cloud is then
imported into Unity.

The in-lab simulation
environment can then be built to be a
digital twin of the real world course and study events
can be staged on the map.

At runtime, we use our
real-time navigation system to locate the vehicle position
and update the headset camera
location in Unity.

So one of my goals
is actually to run one of these pedestrian-driver
interaction studies, but actually in
physical environment.

So we're still trying to figure
out how to make that work. So all I'm showing you are
all these driving simulation

things that help you think
about driving behavior, public behavior. But one of the things
I'm most proud of

is the way that we've
been able to move this towards thinking about
how we interact and design

the community and then
think about how we do future planning for cities. And this next project I think
really captures that very well.

I should mention this one. Best honorable mention at
designing interactive systems this last summer.

Extended realities, XR, has
been proven as a powerful tool to engage communities in an
embodied and intuitive way.

Building on what we have
developed in the CXR system, a communal extended
reality system

for situated on-road
immersive experiences. In simple words, the CXR system
enables a group of people

to use virtual reality headsets
inside a moving vehicle and watch the exact same route
in a virtual digital twin.

The virtual world is geolocated
and progresses in sync with the physical world. In our case, we used it to
simulate flood and climate

change scenarios, but
we believe it could have many other implications. In this paper, we
describe our advances

in modeling of the digital twin
and our technical development and setup of the CXR
system on a moving bus.

The Roosevelt
Island digital twin is created based on the
Open Data of New York City

Department of City Planning with
Google Earth as a reference. We digitally modeled the
educational institutions,

religious complexes,
retail corridor and other essential
buildings along the route

and populated the digital
twin with key objects, including stop signs,
light poles, fire hydrants

and trash cans. With a dynamic environment
system, water level animations,

fish flocking and
floating objects, we were able to visually
narrate nine climate change scenarios immersively
to the participants.

I want to contextualize, when
we did the study of this system that we built, we had
groups that were recruited

from Roosevelt Island. We put it in the local grocery
markets and the local cafes.

And so we had pre-ride focus
groups of up to 12 people. We were asking them
what they think

about climate change, what their
concerns are with flooding. We had everyone ride this bus.

And then we also ran
another focused group after. And what we found is
people are from New York.

They're kind of lefty. They said they recycled cans. They care about climate change. But in the pre-ride things,
the thoughts are very abstract.

They kind of have opinions
that were really general. And in the post-ride
focus group,

everyone is much more nervous. But their concerns are
also much more specific.

What if a flood happens
during the school day? How will parents actually
pick up the children? There's a senior citizen center.

What happens to the people
in the senior citizen center? Who works there? What's going on? And so we think that basically
having everyone in the community

have a chance to have a common
shared experience of what might happen, different
possible futures

makes it possible to have
these conversations about what are concrete things the
community needs to do to plan for possible futures?

And I think this is maybe
the most exciting aspect of the research that we've
been doing in this space.

This ability to give people
the shared experience is a kind of foreground for this
other really important community

social work that
needs to happen. So take away from
this last thread is the simulation is a
great way to understand

these real reactions
to potential futures and that the shared
experiences paved the way for understanding
interaction,

but also generating kind
of resolve for action. And again, this is the
kind of repeated theme.

Like low cost, easily replicable
methods and data sharing make it possible for us to
appreciate the depth and breadth

of the things you have to do
to understand community level differences, which are huge. And then we are sharing
our digital models.

We hope other people will
be excited about doing these things. I think we could do
cool projects where we have different cities, but
running the same infrastructure

underneath and then
do comparisons. I'm going to close up
with thinking about what

HCI brings to urban contexts. I think there's just an
appreciation that HCI folks have

on the ground, in-person,
everyday experience that people who work on urban planning
don't always have.

There's also just a willingness
to invent new tools to get a handle on age old problems. And I think the
number of times, we've

participated in
conversations where people were really
surprised to find their doorways to
other possible worlds

when they are so used to
trying to optimize and work with the same trade offs.

It's really exciting. And then finally, I
think there's just this determination in HCI to
solve problems but with people.

And I think that's
something that I've really enjoyed doing in
New York City and I think is a thing that you can
think about that we as HCI

people bring to problems. And with that, I'll close up. I will mention, my new

has a search. It literally went
up on AJO yesterday. I think it might get
